title.narrative: Investing in Students and Programmes for the Innovative Reform of Education
Invirtiendo en Estudiantes y Programa para la Reforma Innovadora de la Educación
N/A
N/A

description.narrative: 3.1 The goal of the proposed project is to facilitate long-term economic competitiveness through the development of a dynamic education and training system that is aligned with the demands of the economy for skilled human resources. The objective of the operation is to contribute to the internal and external efficiency of the education system through a series of targeted interventions that: (i) prepare young Bahamian children for early academic success and social integration; (ii) mitigate the co-existence of skills shortages, unemployment, and lack of relevance of education and training for youth; (iii) facilitate the seamless transition of Bahamian youth from school to work.

activity-description.narrative: 140 Assistant trainers in general and subject specific teaching techniques trained.
17 teachers and aides trained in New Providence. Training certificates were presented to the teachers. An additional 22 teachers/aides received the training on Long Island, Eleuthra and North Andros
78 Public schools in the Bahamas equiped with computer labs and promethean boards. Teachers and parents trained in inclusive education.
BTVI's Organizational Structure to expand Administrative Capacity completed.

Bridge Program developed and implemented. Increase in the number of students completing the Bridge program from zero to 200 in Phase I, & 500 in Phase II. 91 students completing Prep Program 2010/2011 Academic Year.

Certificate and diploma programs within BTVI in response to immediate and future needs in the trades, construction technology, IT and business office technology developed and approved. Legislation for a semi-autonomous BTVI and its permanent governing body has been sent to cabinet and is under consideration.

Commonwealth of Learning (COL) facilitating online training for teachers, administrators and trainers with 330 participants including Online Tutors workshop with 25 participants. Workshop/seminar in project management (60 participants), Approximately 1,000 persons trained on ICT aspects

Instructional materials and electronic equipment was provided for 3 demonstration schools - Hundreds of computers, Interactive White Boards and other educational technologies purchased and installed in public schools throughout The Bahamas

Over 12,500 students were directly impacted by the upgrade of 38 computer labs throughout schools in New Providence and The Family Islands. These also included upgrades to over 11 libraries and learning resource centres.

Over 200 education stakeholders consisting of educators and other industry related professionals were interviewed and trained during workshops to learn more about how the use of technology can enhance learning and provide future career opportunities for students.
Over 200 teachers awarded $2,000.00 scholarships from GAP for certification at College of The Bahamas, Bahamas Baptist College, Sojourner Douglas College, Success Training College and Omega College
Screening of 4 year olds initiated and ongoing; 725 children screened in 2011 on Andros, Long Island, Eleuthra and New Providence. Over 600 children screened in 2013.

TVET school transformed to a career academy through refurbishing existing facilities completed Model for Career Academy approved by Director and Minister of EducationCareer Academy establishedCC Sweeting School Leadership Team identified
The Laboratory Preschool resource centre is furnished with advanced technology that would prepare the students for the future.

The Magnet Program afforded 10 students the opportunity to attend The College of The Bahamas' Jumpstart Program, gaining tertiary level credits for any international university while in high school. These students also had opportunities to complete internships at local private organizations. 450 teachers of magnet programs were trained in technology and vocational professional development courses in 2012.

The Ministry of Education Science and Technology's headquarters is responsible for planning and upgrading all computer labs within New Providence and The Family Islands with newly installed computers, hardware and software for students.
The approved baseline study confirms, over 1,000 administrators, teachers and parents trained in inclusive education strategies.

The subject labs in 27 schools were upgraded. They were also purchased and installed in the 6 magnet program schools. These labs empasize the implemetation and use of tehcnology within the classrooms where the following subjects are taught: Mathematics, Science, Language Arts, and Technical & Vocational Studies. There was also an upgrade of hardware and software equipment including projectors, and laptops provided for students and teachers in these subject labs.

This accelerated program exposes students to careers in the following fields: pre-engineering, business studies, and hospitality. Initiated in 2009, Anatole Rodgers is among other high schools that have been successful implementing the Magnet Program. Approximately 75 students were trained in technology skills and introduced to new IT equipment. They also participated in the Dual Credit Program at The College of The Bahamas (COB) or The Bahamas Technical and Vocational Institute (BTVI)

This curriculum was developed and approved - Professional Development Sessions for Secondary TVET in New Providence, Grand Bahama and Eleuthera with combined total of 600 TVET teachers participating up to December 2011.Additionally, over 150 teachers trained in 2012 and over 200 for year 2013-2014
